body: I'd go beyond 'useful' and instead call it 'critical', since sass-loader uses `render()`, and realistically, running 1.3.4 isn't possible with the current deluge of deprecation warnings in things like bootstrap.

This is blocked on the importer design of the new JS API, which should allow the evaluator to distinguish which dependencies are actually coming from upstream. Moving this issue to the Sass language repo.

> I'd go beyond 'useful' and instead call it 'critical', since sass-loader uses `render()`, and realistically, running 1.3.4 isn't possible with the current deluge of deprecation warnings in things like bootstrap.

As of 1.34.0, Sass will print at most 5 deprecation warnings of a given type by default, which should make libraries that haven't moved to `math.div()` much more usable.

Thank you for moving to the correct repo.

And indeed it is not unusable on 1.34.0, it just makes it harder to see the deprecation warning on the code you maintain, as the warnings on deps appears first, as we import deps first.

issue.title: support quietDeps flag

repository.name: dart-sass
repository.description: The reference implementation of Sass, written in Dart.

body: We recommend using [the Sass migrator](https://www.npmjs.com/package/sass-migrator) to update your local code anyway, rather than fixing warnings by hand.

issue.title: Stop using / as division

labels.name: planned
labels.description: We would like to add this feature at some point

issue.body:
**The current plan:**

1. Create an automated migration tool that can migrate users from `/`-as-division to a `divide()` function.
2. Deprecate `/`-as-division. Any time a `/` would be interpreted unambiguously as division, or an ambiguous `/` would be made unambiguous (for example by being stored in a variable), we produce a deprecation warning .
3. Add a top-level `divide()` function (`math.div()` in the new module system). This will work exactly the same way division works today, with the obvious exception that it will never be treated as a slash separator.
4. Add a new slash-separated list type to represent slash as a separator. For the time being, this will not have a literal syntax.
5. Add a `slash-list()` function (`list.slash()` in the new module system) that returns a slash-separated list. Providing the ability to work with slash-separated lists even before they have a literal syntax will help stylesheets be forwards-compatible with the new wold.
6. Wait until at least three months after the module system is released.
7. Release Dart Sass 2.0.0, which parses `/` as a list separator that binds more loosely than space but more tightly than comma.
8. Add support for [first class `calc()`](https://github.com/sass/sass/issues/2186), which will allow `/`-as-division in the form of `calc(5px / 2)`.
8. Deprecate the `slash-list()`/`list.slash()` function in favor of using the literal syntax.
9. Whenever Dart Sass 3.0.0 releases, remove `slash-list()` and `list.slash()`.

* [x] [Migrator](https://github.com/sass/migrator/issues/37)
* [x] [Proposal](https://github.com/sass/sass/blob/master/accepted/slash-separator.md)
* Deprecation, `divide()`, and `slash-list()`
  * [x] [Specs](https://github.com/sass/sass-spec/pull/1399)
  * [x] [Dart Sass](https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/issues/663)
  * ~[LibSass](https://github.com/sass/libsass/issues/2887)~
* Removal of /-as-division, deprecation of `slash-list()`
  * [x] Update deprecations (https://github.com/sass/sass/pull/4131)
  * [x] Specs (https://github.com/sass/sass-spec/pull/2086)
  * [x] [Dart Sass](https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/issues/663) (https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/pull/2649)
  * [ ] Sass Site
  * ~[LibSass](https://github.com/sass/libsass/issues/2887)~
* Removal of `slash-list()`
  * [ ] Update deprecations
  * [ ] Specs
  * [ ] [Dart Sass](https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/issues/663)
  * ~[LibSass](https://github.com/sass/libsass/issues/2887)~

---

**The original issue:**

When Sass was first designed, the most prominent use of `/` as a separator in CSS was the short-form [`font` property](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font), which used it to separate values for `font-size` and `line-height`. Because this was a relatively narrow edge case, we were able to use `/` as the division operator as well, with [some heuristics](https://sass-lang.com/documentation/file.SASS_REFERENCE.html#division-and-slash) to decide between them. When `/` was used as a separator, the value it produced was actually the divided number, but it was *rendered* with the slash instead.

However, the slash separator has been seeing more use in recent CSS specs. The [`grid-row`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/grid-row) property uses it to separate values for `grid-row-start` and `grid-row-end`, and [Colors Level 4](https://drafts.csswg.org/css-color/) uses it in many color functions (including the new recommended syntax for `rgb()` and `hsl()`) to separate the alpha value from the rest of the parameters.

The increased prominence of this syntax means that the sharp edges of the heuristics we use to distinguish between `/`-as-separator and `/`-as-division will start cutting more users. Once Sass supports the new color function syntax (https://github.com/sass/sass/issues/2564), users are likely to try passing the alpha by variable, which will currently fail. We need to decide whether to do something about this, and if so, what.

## How do we represent division?

Today, division is represented by the operator `/`, which as discussed above is ambiguous. We could fairly easily add a new syntax for this, which would allow us to migrate users away from `/`, eventually leaving it as unambiguously a separator.

I see a few options for this:

* Keep the behavior as-is. This has the substantial benefit of requiring no migration, and it will be sufficient to support compatibility with plain CSS. However, it will make it much more painful for users to use dynamic alpha values for their colors as the new color function syntax gains traction.

* Replace the `/` operator with another operator. There's no option that's really consistent with other programming languages, but `~` is a possibility that's currently unused and looks a *little* like รท.
https://github.com/sass/sass/issues/2565
* Replace the `/` operator with a function, such as `div()`. This is more verbose, but it's very clear to the reader and it avoids any risk of further collision with new CSS syntax.

## What is a slash separator?

If we do decide to free up `/` to unambiguously represent a separator, we need to figure out how that separator works in terms of SassScript. This is particularly tricky because its scope varies from property to property. In `font`, it's *tightly bound*--the slash in `italic small-caps bold 16px/2 cursive` separates `16px` from `2`, but it *doesn't* separate `italic small-caps bold 16px` from `2 cursive`. However, in `grid-row` and the color functions, it's *loosely bound*--the slash in `rgb(1 2 3 / 0.5)` separates `1 2 3` from `0.5`, and is not bound to `3` in particular.

I think it makes sense in general to consider `/` another kind of list separator, so that it works smoothly with existing APIs. But because of the scoping differences it's not clear whether it should bind more tightly than space-separated lists or not. That is, should `1 2 / 3 4` be equivalent to `(1 2) / (3 4)` or `1 (2 / 3) 4`?

body: This is critical, I import Angular Components and have no control over whether they've taken care of deprecated code. After switching from node-sass to sass, my build logs are spammed with stuff I can't suppress. It totally screws up dev workflows if you relying on a terminal.
If you upgrade to Dart Sass 1.34, it'll only print the first five warnings of a given type by default. That should keep you from being totally deluged until we're able to add support for `quietDeps`.
Already done, but still a fair amount of text. No biggie not end of the world for me
+1 for `quietDeps` support in the JS API!

issue.title: Quasar v2 (Vue 3) - released!

repository.name: quasar
repository.description: Quasar Framework - Build high-performance VueJS user interfaces in record time

issue.body:
**Quasar v2 is out!** Read our [announcement](https://github.com/quasarframework/quasar/discussions/9734).

## Is v2 stable?

**YES**

## The plan

Our main focus at the moment is shipping Quasar v2 with Vue v3.
The plan is to **not introduce any breaking changes**, unless forced by the vue 3 / vue-router 4 architectures.

Affected Quasar packages: "quasar", "@quasar/app".

## Rough schedule

* First beta: "quasar" v2.0.0-beta.1 & "@quasar/app" v3.0.0-beta.1 - **Jan 2021**
* Stable releases: "quasar" v2.0.0 & "@quasar/app" v3.0.0 - **Q2 2021**

## The code

The branch currently holding Quasar v2 is called [dev](https://github.com/quasarframework/quasar/tree/dev) (was previously `vue3-work`).

## Donations

If you want to speed up the development of Quasar please consider donating to the project. With proper funding, it allows more of the team to work on the project in a much more dedicated manner.

[Donations - https://donate.quasar.dev](https://donate.quasar.dev)

If you're in a company and using Quasar for commercial projects, explain to your management the importance of monthly donations (eg. $200+) for open source projects: you're the one using it every day and this makes you the best suited person to convince them. Be creative! :slight_smile:

Quasar is saving your company tens of thousands of development hours (quite literally), which in turn is a pretty high money savings. Consider giving back a part of those savings to refuel the project itself :wink:

## Update: June 21st 2021

Quasar v2 stable (with Vue.js 3) has been released! Time to party!
https://github.com/quasarframework/quasar/discussions/9734

## Update: June 19th 2021

Next release is v2.0.0 stable.
Branch `vue3-work` has been merged into `dev`. The Qv1 work will now be done exclusively on the new `v1` branch.

## Update: April 27th 2021
We have passed the final major milestone: Quasar CLI now ships with Webpack 5, which was badly needed to support Node 13+. Faster build speeds and lower memory usage.
We're just a few small steps away from getting Quasar v2 out of beta!

## Update: April 4th 2021
The last Quasar CLI mode left to be enabled, which is SSR, is now also available.
Here is the link to the [upgrade guide](https://next.quasar.dev/quasar-cli/developing-ssr/ssr-upgrade-guide) on SSR.
We are targeting for a 2 weeks testing period for SSR mode then we will release the official stable version of Quasar v2.

## Update: February 16th 2021

We're close to the stable release. The only thing remaining is the SSR support. Quasar is SSR ready, however we're only going to enable SSR support as soon as these Vue3 SSR bugs (critical for us and your experience) are solved:
* ~https://github.com/vuejs/vue-next/issues/3244~ redirected to https://github.com/vuejs/vue-next/issues/2863
* https://github.com/vuejs/vue-next/issues/2386
* https://github.com/vuejs/vue-next/issues/3245
* https://github.com/vuejs/vue-next/issues/3243
* https://github.com/vuejs/vue-next/issues/3255

## Update: February 10th 2021

SSR mode is ready (UI and CLI-wise) to be released. Unfortunately, there are quite a few Vue SSR bugs that need to be fixed before we enable the build mode for Quasar v2. We are in the process of reporting them and we'll start collaborating with the Vue team to help fix them.

## Update: January 11th 2021

Hi All,

There are still some things being worked on for Quasar v2, but mainly we're now writing the migration guide. Our target for release of the public beta is within January 2021. The new version is based on Composition API. But it's not just a port to Vue 3. _There are lots of significant performance enhancements in Quasar's algorithms too!_ **You'll love it!**

Unfortunately, the first beta release won't include SSR support, due to missing some upstream features in Vue 3, which we'll contribute to via PRs. We'll release SSR support during the beta stage lifecycle though.

We're also trying to integrate Webpack 5 support into the `@quasar/app` v3 release, but if we are unable to get this done (ie: external dependencies and such) then we'll shoot for `@quasar/app` v4 release.

Stable release will be anywhere within Q1 2021, but as is the case with OSS, it will be ready, when it's ready. And of course, it will be ready when we know the quality is high enough to meet both your expectations and ours.

In the meantime, the wonderful framework you've come to love is still here and you don't have to wait for Quasar v2 to start a new project with Vue 3's major new feature (i.e. using the composition API). Of course, if you choose to hold off on Vue 3 features, we'll make the upgrade as easy as possible for you. That's a promise. :slight_smile:

The Quasar Team

issue.title: Add a --quiet-upstream flag

repository.name: dart-sass
repository.description: The reference implementation of Sass, written in Dart.

issue.body:
Most users only have the capacity to fix deprecation warnings in their own code, but they may end up using libraries that have their own deprecation warnings. We should add a `--quiet-upstream` flag (and similar flags for the Dart and JS APIs) to silence deprecation warnings emitted by upstream libraries (that is, libraries loaded through load paths and `package:` URLs). 

I think this flag should probably *not* silence warnings due to `@warn`, since libraries frequently use those to indicate that downstream users are using the library in an invalid or deprecated way.

body: I have a question and I'm not sure where else to ask and I read a few of these comments/issues... I'm using dart-sass in an Open Source lib and I upgraded to latest version and I did add the `math.div()` but I'm worried about is, what happens to all the users of my lib if they haven't upgrade to the latest version of dart-sass (or what if they're still using node-sass)? Will that break on their side? I would prefer warnings over breakage and so I'm strongly considering reverting to the previous version (1.32.0) to avoid breaking changes and stick on that version for a few months. Could someone provide guidance on that before I revert everything? Am I right or wrong thinking this might break users of my lib?

@ghiscoding: The `math.div` method was added recently:
https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/commit/be1a414f07bdc2a862ead7d349f2195216dbf6dc
Since [release 1.33.0](https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/releases/tag/1.33.0).
Documentation: https://sass-lang.com/documentation/breaking-changes/slash-div#transition-period

How is the SCSS used by your team? As long as you add the required SASS compiler and version (dart-sass; 1.33.0) as requirements, it should be clear when updating is necessary. On the other hand, updating the existing builders/chain can be painful sometimes for older/legacy projects.

Thanks for replying but the info you provided I already knew all of that. When I say users of my lib, I mean hundreds of users in the world, I maintain Open Source libs and I have no clue what tool and versions they might be using, I wouldn't be surprised that many of them are still using node-sass. So I'll ask again, upgrading my lib to latest and add `math.div()`, will that break any users using old version of dart-sass and node-sass? My expectation is yes but I would really like a clear answer (to me this looks like a breaking change)

We have the very same problem into Quasar Framework. All these deprecation warnings, without a way to silence them (ALL of them) create an horrible DX. We don't really know how to react to this change, as it corner us in many ways.

Either we pin a previous version and risk having to update it later on if a security problem arises, or we flood our users with warnings, many of those they have no control on. And if we try to update our code to avoid those warnings, all our users codebases will just break

@ghiscoding @IlCallo I think you can temporarily use a solution similar to the one used in Angular Material https://github.com/angular/components/commit/a4043f41f539ed910c80c780e1815f5625282b94#diff-4b0d3692fae1e26970f5365a78db4ff81acb362f79ef12252081df8b285d38e8. Its main idea is to use a polyfill for `math.div`.

Nice one! But this would help only with the `/` problem.
~The other one we have is about the import style. Are you aware of any workaround for that?~
I may have misunderstood something about this second one, I'm checking if it actually affect us in some way

issue.title: sass: / is deprecated for division

repository.name: patternfly
repository.description: This repo contains core (HTML/CSS) implementation for PatternFly. Issues related to CSS/HTML and layout should be filed here.

issue.body:
https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/releases/tag/1.33.0

https://sass-lang.com/documentation/breaking-changes/slash-div

If `sass` version 1.33.0 or newer is installed, the console is absolutely flooded by "/ is deprecated for division" errors when patternfly builds.
